latest news.eng_title: Most Fed officials favour a rate cut in September if inflation continues to cool
latest news.summary: Most Federal Reserve officials agree that they will likely cut their benchmark interest rate in September if inflation continues to cool. The minutes of the Fed's July meeting revealed that the 'vast majority' of policymakers believe it would be 'appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting' if data continues to come in as expected. This would be the first interest rate cut in four years and could lead to lower rates for auto loans, mortgages, and other forms of consumer borrowing, as well as boost stock prices. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is expected to provide further guidance on the Fed's next steps in a highly anticipated speech on Friday, where he may signal that the Fed has become confident that inflation is headed back to its 2% target and hint at the number of rate cuts that could happen this year.
latest news.title: Most Fed officials favour a rate cut in September if inflation continues to cool

latest news.eng_title: Most Officials Favor A Rate Cut In September If Inflation Continued To Cool
latest news.summary: Most Federal Reserve officials agreed that they would likely cut their benchmark interest rate in September if inflation continued to cool, according to the minutes of the Fed's July 30-31 meeting. The 'vast majority' of policymakers 'observed that, if the data continued to come in about as expected, it would likely be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting.' This would lead to lower rates for auto loans, mortgages, and other forms of consumer borrowing, and could also boost stock prices. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is expected to signal in his speech at the annual symposium of central bankers in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, that the Fed has become confident that inflation is headed back to its 2% target and might even give some hint about how many rate cuts could happen this year. Powell had previously suggested that a broad range of policy moves were possible, from 'zero cuts to several cuts,' by year's end. Recent economic data, including a healthy pace of retail sales and a decline in unemployment benefits, suggests that consumers are still willing to spend and help power the economy.
latest news.title: Most Officials Favor A Rate Cut In September If Inflation Continued To Cool

latest news.eng_title: US stock futures steady as rate cut cheer grows
latest news.summary: US stock index futures rose slightly on Wednesday evening, extending gains from Wall Street as the minutes of the Federal Reserve's recent meeting fueled growing conviction that the central bank will cut rates. The minutes showed an increasing number of policymakers supported lowering interest rates amid progress in bringing down inflation. Analysts at Citi see a 50 bps reduction as their base case for September, especially after Wednesday's minutes showed more officials leaning towards lower rates. The S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 5,620.85 points on Wednesday, while the NASDAQ Composite rose 0.6% to 17,817.99 points. However, gains in Wall Street were held back by anticipation of an address by Fed Chair Jerome Powell at the Jackson Hole Symposium on Friday, where he is expected to reiterate the central bank's dovish stance, setting the stage for a September rate cut.
latest news.title: US stock futures steady as rate cut cheer grows

latest news.eng_title: Federal Reserve Minutes Suggest Interest Rate Cut Possible in September
latest news.summary: According to the minutes of the Federal Reserve meeting, officials approached a potential interest rate cut in July, and a majority of participants 'if data continues to come in as expected, it would be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting' in September. While all members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted to keep interest rates unchanged, there was a trend among some officials to begin easing in July rather than waiting until September. As CNBC reported, the minutes stated that 'the majority' of participants 'if data continues to come in as expected, it would be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting' in September.
latest news.title: محضر الفيدرالي: تخفيض سعر الفائدة بات محتملا في سبتمبر

latest news.eng_title: Federal Reserve Meeting Minutes Suggest Rate Cut in September
latest news.summary: The Federal Reserve's meeting minutes from July 30-31 showed that most policymakers agreed that they would likely lower the federal funds rate in September if inflation continued to decline. The minutes stated that 'the majority' of policymakers 'noted that if the data continues to appear as expected, it would be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting.' The Federal Reserve kept the federal funds rate at 5.3% in July, which is the highest level in nearly a quarter century. Market participants have already considered it certain that the Federal Reserve will announce its first rate cut in four years when it meets on September 17-18. A rate cut by the Federal Reserve would ultimately lead to a decrease in car loan and mortgage interest rates, and could also lead to an increase in stock prices. The meeting minutes also highlighted that 'many' policymakers believe that the current interest rate stance is restrictive, while 'a few' participants argued that leaving the interest rate unchanged would increase pressure on the economy. Despite all Federal Reserve officials agreeing to keep the interest rate steady in July, the minutes noted that 'many' policymakers believed that the progress in lowering inflation, combined with rising unemployment rates, 'provided a reasonable argument for reducing the 25-basis-point target range.' The Federal Reserve maintained its monetary policy settings for the eighth consecutive meeting in July, as widely expected. In its policy statement, the central bank said it is 'attentive to risks on both sides of its dual mandate,' a change from its June statement, which said it was 'highly attentive' to inflation risks. Although the Federal Reserve reiterated that it does not expect to cut interest rates until it has more confidence that inflation is moving sustainably towards 2%, statements by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell in the post-meeting press conference effectively confirmed a rate cut in September. Powell said, 'We are approaching the point where we would be cutting rates,' and added that cutting interest rates might be considered in September. He also noted that there was 'a real discussion' about cutting interest rates at the July meeting. Powell's cautious comments and the soft labor market data allowed the markets to price in a 25-basis-point rate cut in September. According to the CME FedWatch tool, the probability of a 50-basis-point rate cut had risen to nearly 50% earlier in August. With the upbeat retail sales for July and the weekly jobless claims data that eased concerns about the economic slowdown in the United States, the chances of a large rate cut of 25% have decreased.
latest news.title: محضر اجتماع الفيدرالي الأمريكي.. توجهات نحو خفض الفائدة في سبتمبر

latest news.eng_title: Fed officials agreed September interest rate cut looked likely, meeting minutes show
latest news.summary: According to the minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting in late July, the 'vast majority' of officials believed that the central bank would likely cut interest rates in September. This is the clearest indication yet that the Fed is on track to cut interest rates next month for the first time since 2020, as worries about the health of the economy mount. The minutes stated that 'if the data continued to come in about as expected, it would likely be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting.' The Fed unanimously voted to hold rates at a range between 5.25% to 5.5% at the meeting, but 'almost all' officials said that the factors that have pushed inflation down 'would likely continue' in the coming months, including the slowing economy and consumer pushback on high prices. This confirms what financial markets have long been expecting, and Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell will speak on the economic outlook on Friday at the central bank's annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.
latest news.title: Fed officials agreed September interest rate cut looked likely, meeting minutes show

latest news.eng_title: Fed Minutes Showed Officials Discussed July Rate Cut, Ready to Cut in September
latest news.summary: Federal Reserve officials discussed cutting interest rates in July, but ultimately decided to hold them steady. However, they noted that a rate cut in September could be appropriate if the data continues to come in as expected. Since the meeting, the data have likely strengthened the case for a September rate cut, particularly after a weaker-than-expected July jobs report. The minutes from the Federal Open Market Committee's July 30-31 meeting stated that 'the vast majority observed that, if the data continued to come in about as expected, it would likely be appropriate to ease policy at the next meeting.' Officials also noted that inflation was becoming less of a concern, with 'almost all participants observed that the factors that had contributed to recent disinflation would likely continue to put downward pressure on inflation in coming months.' The next batch of data will arrive before the September meeting, including August jobs data on Sept. 6 and the August Consumer Price Index on Sept. 11. Interest-rate futures markets are pricing in about 62% odds of a quarter-point reduction in the fed-funds rate in September. 'Most participants remarked on the importance of communicating the Committee's data-dependent approach and emphasized, in particular, that monetary policy decisions are conditional on the evolution of the economy rather than being on a preset path or that those decisions depend on the totality of the incoming data rather than on any particular data point,' the minutes read. 'These factors included a continued waning of pricing power, moderating economic growth, and the runoff in excess household savings accumulated during the pandemic.' The softening labor market was also responsible for some of the slowing inflation by putting less upward pressure on wages. Going forward, officials were watching for developments on both the inflation and employment sides of their mandate. 'Some participants noted that as conditions in the labor market have eased, the risk had increased that continued easing could transition to a more serious deterioration,' the minutes read. 'As sources of upside risks to inflation, some participants cited the potential for disruptions to supply chains and a further deterioration in geopolitical conditions.'
latest news.title: Fed Minutes Showed Officials Discussed July Rate Cut, Ready to Cut in September

latest news.eng_title: Fed's July Meeting Suggests Depth of Discussion on Cutting Interest Rates
latest news.summary: The Federal Reserve's (Fed) July meeting showed a deeper discussion on cutting interest rates in the US. The Fed kept its interest rate between 5.25% and 5.50%, but made significant changes to its statement, opening the door for a potential cut in the next meeting. Fed Chair Jerome Powell said, 'If we see inflation falling... roughly in line with expectations, growth continuing reasonably strong and the labor market consistent with current conditions, then I think a cut in the rate could be on the table for the September meeting.' However, recent data from the US Department of Labor showed a strong slowdown in job creation in July, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.3%, a post-pandemic high. This led to a surge in market volatility and some Fed officials indicating they would consider cutting rates in September. Neel Kashkari, President of the Fed of Minneapolis, said, 'The risk balance has shifted, so the debate about cutting rates in September is appropriate.' Previously, Kashkari emphasized the importance of ensuring inflation returns to the Fed's 2% target, even if that means keeping rates steady until late this year.
latest news.title: Ata da reunião de julho do Fed deve mostrar profundidade de debate sobre corte de juros nos EUA

latest news.eng_title: Will the Federal Reserve Give Signals on Interest Rate Cut at Jackson Hole?
latest news.summary: The world is looking to the Jackson Hole meetings from August 22-24 for signals on the future monetary policy of the US Federal Reserve, amid widespread expectations that the first interest rate cut in the US will be in September, by 0.25% according to most forecasts. The US interest rate has been at 5.5% since July 2023, after the Federal Reserve kept it steady for eight consecutive meetings. The data on the Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index, which will be released on August 30, and the employment report outside the agricultural sector, which will be released on September 6, will play a crucial role in the Federal Reserve's decision at its next meeting on September 17-18. Gold markets are retreating from a record high as investors await signs of a rate cut. The latest data for July was reassuring, with the economy showing signs of strength and resilience, whether it was the decline in inflation, which is gradually decreasing, despite not yet reaching the target level of 2%, or the positive numbers for the Producer Price Index (PPI) and retail sales, which were stronger than expected, or the weekly unemployment benefits, which fell for the second consecutive week. While the Federal Reserve is still holding back on cutting interest rates, major central banks have already taken this step. The Bank of Canada was the first major central bank to cut interest rates, on June 5, by 0.25% to 4.75%, and then again on July 24, by 0.25% to 4.5%. After the release of the Canadian inflation data for July yesterday, which was 2.5% in line with expectations, the Bank of Canada remains on the right track to cut interest rates for the third consecutive meeting in the coming month. The European Central Bank cut interest rates for the first time in five years on June 6, by 0.25% to 3.75%, after keeping it steady for five consecutive meetings. On August 1, the Bank of England cut interest rates by 0.25% to 5%, after keeping it steady for seven consecutive meetings. The Swiss National Bank has cut interest rates twice this year, in March and June, by 0.25% each time, leaving interest rates at 1.25%. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut interest rates by 0.25% to 5.25% on August 8, after keeping it steady for eight consecutive meetings at 5.5% since May 2023. The Swedish Riksbank cut interest rates by 0.25% to 3.5% yesterday, for the second time this year, after cutting it 0.25% also in May. According to ATFX MENA's chief market analyst, Kabi Dahdoh, the Jackson Hole conference may give some indications on the direction of the Federal Reserve. Dahdoh added in an interview with Al Arabiya Business that the employment data is the key in determining the percentage of interest rate cut. He explained that with the start of the series of interest rate cuts, investors are now monitoring the US dollar.
latest news.title: هل يصدر "الفيدرالي" إشارات في "جاكسون هول" لخفض الفائدة؟

news knowledge.eng_title: US Fed must go big with 50 bps interest rate cut in September or risk recession: Experts | Mint
news knowledge.summary: Wall Street experts believe that the US Federal Reserve must implement a significant 50 basis point interest rate cut in September to avoid a potential recession. The Fed has maintained the benchmark interest rate at 5.25-5.50% for the eighth consecutive meeting, in line with market expectations. As the US central bank has kept borrowing rates steady for 12 months to combat inflation, experts warn that a more substantial rate cut is necessary to mitigate the looming economic storm.
news knowledge.title: US Fed must go big with 50 bps interest rate cut in September or risk recession: Experts | Mint

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed expected to cut rates by 25 bps at September meeting: economist survey
news knowledge.summary: A recent survey of 51 economists by Bloomberg found that most expect the Federal Reserve to cut their benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points at their next meeting in September, contrary to calls for a 50-bp cut or an inter-meeting move. The economists' view aligns with Fed officials' statements that the central bank will be deliberate and patient in setting policy. Stephanie Roth, chief economist at Wolfe Research, said, 'We think financial markets might force the Fed to cut inter-meeting but otherwise don't think last week's data is enough of a reason.' The survey found that 60% of economists described the labor market as solid, though somewhat softened, while 24% called it significantly weakened but likely to stabilize. Traders, however, are leaning toward a 50-bp cut at the Sept. 17-18 meeting, giving that outcome a 54.5% probability vs. a 45.5% probability for a 25-bp reduction.
news knowledge.title: Fed expected to cut rates by 25 bps at September meeting: economist survey

news knowledge.eng_title: US Fed holds rates, signals possible cut in September
news knowledge.summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady at 5.25-5.5% in its July meeting, but signaled a possible rate cut in September. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated that if inflation moves in line with expectations, 'a reduction in our policy rate could be on the table' in the September meeting. The Dow Jones index rose with markets anticipating greater visibility on interest rate cuts. The Fed's policy statement noted 'some further progress' towards achieving the 2% inflation target, with inflation rising 2.5% in June. The committee is shifting focus from solely fixating on inflation to being 'attentive to the risks to both sides of its dual mandate' -- inflation and employment. The unemployment rate in the US has risen to 4.1%. This could have implications for emerging economies, as the International Monetary Fund noted that 'a number of central banks in emerging market economies remain cautious in regard to cutting rates owing to external risks triggered by changes in interest rate differentials and associated depreciation of those economies' currencies against the dollar.'
news knowledge.title: US Fed holds rates, signals possible cut in September

news knowledge.eng_title: US Fed holds rates steady, nods to possible September cut - ETCFO
news knowledge.summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady on Wednesday, but hinted at a possible rate cut in September. The central bank's Federal Open Market Committee stated that there has been 'some further progress' towards its 2% inflation target, citing the steady drop in inflation in recent months. This decision sets the stage for a potential rate cut at the Fed's September meeting, just before the US elections.
news knowledge.title: US Fed holds rates steady, nods to possible September cut - ETCFO

news knowledge.eng_title: The Fed Is Holding Interest Rates Steady, but Cuts Are Coming Soon
news knowledge.summary: The Federal Reserve has decided to hold interest rates steady at 5.25% to 5.5%, as expected, but rate cuts are anticipated in September. Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that inflation has eased, but remains above the Fed's target, and that the committee wants to see 'further progress' before lowering rates. Powell signaled that an interest rate cut is coming 'as soon as the next meeting' if inflation continues to cool and the labor market remains stable. Analysts predict a 100% probability of a September rate cut, with most expecting a 0.25 percentage point reduction. The Fed will closely monitor inflation and jobs data between now and September to determine the extent of the cut. The decision means consumers must weather high interest rates for at least a little longer, with borrowers facing record-high mortgage and credit card payments. However, interest rates remaining steady mean larger yields on certificates of deposit and high-yield savings accounts. The stock market has had a strong performance on Wednesday, with the Dow, S&P, and Nasdaq indexes up more than 1%, 2%, and 3%, respectively, as investors adjust to potentially lower rates.
news knowledge.title: The Fed Is Holding Interest Rates Steady, but Cuts Are Coming Soon

news knowledge.summary: The Federal Reserve has decided to keep interest rates steady at a 22-year high, between 5.25% and 5.5%, citing mixed economic data and a need for more confidence that inflation is moving towards its target of 2%. The Fed's statement suggests that it may wait longer than expected to cut rates, potentially throwing cold water on investors' expectations of a September cut. As stated by the Fed, 'The Committee does not expect it will be appropriate to reduce the target range until it has gained greater confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2 percent.' The next scheduled meeting is in September, with potential cuts in November and December. Prior to the meeting, financial markets had predicted a 100% chance of a September cut and high odds of further cuts this year.
news knowledge.title: Fed Holds Rates Steady

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Signals September Cut Amid Cooling Inflation
news knowledge.summary: The Federal Reserve has decided to maintain interest rates at 5.25% to 5.5%, but signaled a potential rate cut in September due to easing inflation and a cooling labor market. The committee's post-meeting statement acknowledged the moderation in job gains and the slight rise in the unemployment rate, while noting that inflation remains 'somewhat elevated.' Economists and investors expect a rate cut in September, and the Fed will closely monitor labor market trends and inflation to achieve a balanced risk between inflation and employment. According to Chair Jerome Powell, the Fed's goal is to foster maximum employment, and the rise in the unemployment rate to 4.1% and the slowdown in hiring underscore the Fed's cautious stance. As inflation trends more favorably towards the 2% target, the September meeting is poised to be pivotal, with Powell's upcoming press conference being closely watched for further insights into the central bank's strategies.
news knowledge.title: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Signals September Cut Amid Cooling Inflation

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed Meeting Today: No Interest Rate Cut, but September Looks Promising
news knowledge.summary: The Federal Reserve has voted to keep interest rates steady at 5.25-5.50% for the eighth consecutive time, but its statement suggests 'some further progress' on inflation, indicating that inflation is decreasing. Most experts predict an interest rate cut in September, which could bring relief to Americans waiting for rates to drop before taking out a new loan or mortgage, or paying off high-interest credit card debt. The Fed has been holding interest rates at a 23-year high since last summer to bring inflation down to its target of 2%.
news knowledge.title: Fed Meeting Today: No Interest Rate Cut, but September Looks Promising

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed holds interest rates steady and stops short of signaling September cut
news knowledge.summary: The Federal Reserve held its interest rate target steady at 5.25% to 5.50% for the eighth consecutive meeting, despite investor expectations of a potential cut in the coming months. The Fed stated that its goals for the labor market and inflation 'continue to move into better balance,' but stopped short of signaling a rate cut at the next meeting in September. The decision comes as inflation has been falling, with the consumer price index dropping to 3% for the year ending in June, a 0.3-point decline more than predicted by economists. The Fed's multiyear projections indicate that inflation will fall to 2.6% by the end of 2024 and the unemployment rate will be 4% by the end of this year. The economy has been expanding at a healthy pace, despite high-interest-rate environment, with a 1.4% growth rate in the first quarter of this year.
news knowledge.title: Fed holds interest rates steady and stops short of signaling September cut

news knowledge.eng_title: Fed Expected to Hold Rates and Signal September Cut
news knowledge.summary: Federal Reserve officials are expected to hold interest rates steady at 5.25-5.5% this week, but signal a potential rate cut in September. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg News predict that the Fed will acknowledge progress in reducing inflation, which is a prerequisite for rate cuts. Fed Chair Jerome Powell will hold a press conference after the meeting, where he may be asked about the outlook for the next meeting in September and the pace of easing for the rest of the year. Some economists, including Subadra Rajappa of Societe Generale, believe that the Fed will change its language in the statement to suggest a cut at the September meeting. 'I think that they are going to change the language in the statement to suggest a cut at the September meeting,' said Rajappa. Rate Decision: All economists surveyed by Bloomberg are looking for no change in rates at this meeting. Markets have fully priced in a Fed rate cut in September, but the big question is how clearly the FOMC will signal this. 'We think communications from the July meeting will offer only tentative hints of a September cut, with Fed Chair Jerome Powell noting the potential for a cut 'if data evolve as we expect,' said Bloomberg Economics. 'Powell could be asked about what would meet the bar for the 'unexpected weakening' that makes them reassess whether quarterly 25 basis point cuts are enough,' said Derek Tang, an economist with LH Meyer/Monetary Policy Analytics.
news knowledge.title: Fed Expected to Hold Rates and Signal September Cut
